SPEAR: Exact Gradient Inversion of Batches in Federated Learning

 

Dimitar I. Dimitrov 1  Maximilian Baader 1  Mark Niklas Müller 1  Martin Vechev 1 


††footnotetext: 1Department of Computer Science, ETH Zurich, Zurich, Switzerland. Correspondence to: Dimitar I. Dimitrov <dimitadi@inf.ethz.ch>.  
Abstract

Federated learning is a popular framework for collaborative machine learning where multiple clients only share gradient updates on their local data with the server and not the actual data. Unfortunately, it was recently shown that gradient inversion attacks can reconstruct this data from these shared gradients. Existing attacks enable exact reconstruction only for a batch size of b=1𝑏1b=1 in the important honest-but-curious setting, with larger batches permitting only approximate reconstruction. In this work, we propose the first algorithm reconstructing whole batches with b>1𝑏1b>1 exactly. This approach combines mathematical insights into the explicit low-rank structure of gradients with a sampling-based algorithm. Crucially, we leverage ReLU-induced gradient sparsity to precisely filter out large numbers of incorrect samples, making a final reconstruction step tractable. We provide an efficient GPU implementation for fully connected networks and show that it recovers batches of b≲25less-than-or-similar-to𝑏25b\lesssim 25 elements exactly while being tractable for large network widths and depths.

1 Introduction

Federated learning

has emerged as the dominant paradigm for training machine learning models collaboratively without sharing sensitive data (McMahan et al., 2017). Instead, a central server sends the current model to all clients which then compute gradients with their private data and send them back to the server. There, the gradients are aggregated and used to update the model. Using this approach sensitive data never leaves the clients’ machines, aligning it better with data privacy regulations such as the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) and California Consumer Privacy Act (CCPA).

Gradient Inversion Attacks

Recent work has shown that an honest-but-curious server can use the shared gradient updates to reconstruct the sensitive client data (Zhu et al., 2019; Dimitrov et al., 2022). However, while exact reconstruction was shown to be possible for batch sizes of b=1𝑏1b=1 (Phong et al., 2018; Zhu & Blaschko, 2021), it was assumed to be infeasible for larger batches. This led to a line of research on approximate methods that sacrificed reconstruction quality in order to recover batches of b>1𝑏1b>1 inputs Geng et al. (2021); Vero et al. (2022); Kariyappa et al. (2023). In this paper we challenge this fundamental assumption and, for the first time, show that exact reconstruction is possible for batch sizes b>1𝑏1b>1.

This Work: Exact Reconstruction of Batches

We propose the first gradient inversion attack reconstructing inputs exactly for batch sizes b>1𝑏1b>1 in the honest-but-curious setting. We illustrate the resulting reconstruction quality in Figure 1, comparing it to approximate reconstructions for a batch of b=20𝑏20b=20 images (Geiping et al., 2020).

Our approach leverages two key properties of gradient updates in fully connected ReLU networks: First, these gradients have a specific low-rank structure due to small batch sizes b≪n,mmuch-less-than𝑏𝑛𝑚b\ll n,m compared to the input dimensionality n𝑛n and the hidden dimension m𝑚m. Second, the (unknown) gradients with respect to the inputs of the first ReLU layer are sparse due to the ReLU function itself. We now combine these properties with ideas from sparsely-used dictionary learning Spielman et al. (2012) to propose a sampling-based algorithm, called SPEAR (Sparsity Exploiting Activation Recovery) and show that it succeeds with high probability for b<m𝑏𝑚b<m. While SPEAR scales exponentially with batch size b𝑏b, we provide a highly parallelized GPU implementation of SPEAR, which empirically allows us to reconstruct batches of size up to b≲25less-than-or-similar-to𝑏25b\lesssim 25 exactly even for large inputs (TinyImageNet) and networks (widths up to 200020002000 and depths up to 999) in around one minute.

Main Contributions:

  • •

    The first method to exactly reconstruct complete batches of size b>1𝑏1b\!>\!1 in the honest-but-curious setting.

  • •

    SPEAR: an algorithm that leverages low rankness and ReLU-induced sparsity of gradients in a highly parallelizable sampling-based algorithm for exact gradient inversion that succeeds with high probability.

  • •

    A highly parallelized GPU implementation of SPEAR, which we empirically demonstrate to be effective across a wide range of settings.

2 Method Overview

We first introduce our setting before giving a high-level overview of our gradient inversion attack SPEAR. A depiction of SPEAR is provided in Figure 2.

Setting

We consider a neural network 𝒇𝒇{\bm{f}} containing a linear layer 𝒛=𝑾​𝒙+𝒃𝒛𝑾𝒙𝒃{\bm{z}}={\bm{W}}{\bm{x}}+{\bm{b}} followed by ReLU activations 𝒚=ReLU⁡(𝒛)𝒚ReLU𝒛{\bm{y}}=\operatorname{ReLU}({\bm{z}}) trained with some loss function ℒℒ\mathcal{L}. Let now 𝑿∈ℝn×b𝑿superscriptℝ𝑛𝑏{\bm{X}}\in\mathbb{R}^{n\times b} be a batch of b𝑏b inputs to this linear layer 𝒁=𝑾​𝑿+(𝒃​|…|​𝒃)𝒁𝑾𝑿𝒃…𝒃{\bm{Z}}={\bm{W}}{\bm{X}}+({\bm{b}}|\dots|{\bm{b}}), with weights 𝑾∈ℝm×n𝑾superscriptℝ𝑚𝑛{\bm{W}}\in\mathbb{R}^{m\times n}, bias 𝒃∈ℝm𝒃superscriptℝ𝑚{\bm{b}}\in\mathbb{R}^{m} and output 𝒁∈ℝm×b𝒁superscriptℝ𝑚𝑏{\bm{Z}}\in\mathbb{R}^{m\times b}. Further, let 𝒀∈ℝm×b𝒀superscriptℝ𝑚𝑏{\bm{Y}}\in\mathbb{R}^{m\times b} be the result of applying the ReLU activation to 𝒁𝒁{\bm{Z}}, i.e., 𝒀=ReLU⁡(𝒁)𝒀ReLU𝒁{\bm{Y}}=\operatorname{ReLU}({\bm{Z}}) and assume b≤m,n𝑏𝑚𝑛b\leq m,n.

The goal of gradient inversion now is to recover the inputs 𝑿𝑿{\bm{X}} (up to permutation) given the gradients ∂ℒ∂𝑾ℒ𝑾\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial{\bm{W}}} and ∂ℒ∂𝒃ℒ𝒃\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial{\bm{b}}} (see Figure 2, i).

Low-Rank Decomposition

We first show that the weight gradient ∂ℒ∂𝑾=∂ℒ∂𝒁​𝑿⊤ℒ𝑾ℒ𝒁superscript𝑿top\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial{\bm{W}}}=\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial{\bm{Z}}}{\bm{X}}^{\top} naturally has a low rank b≤m,n𝑏𝑚𝑛b\leq m,n (Theorem 3.1) and can therefore be decomposed as ∂ℒ∂𝑾=𝑳​𝑹ℒ𝑾𝑳𝑹\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial{\bm{W}}}={\bm{L}}{\bm{R}} into the two matrices 𝑳∈ℝm×b𝑳superscriptℝ𝑚𝑏{\bm{L}}\in\mathbb{R}^{m\times b} and 𝑹∈ℝb×n𝑹superscriptℝ𝑏𝑛{\bm{R}}\in\mathbb{R}^{b\times n} using SVD (Figure 2, ii). We then prove the existence disaggregation matrix 𝑸=(𝒒1​|…|​𝒒b)∈GLb​(ℝ)𝑸subscript𝒒1…subscript𝒒𝑏subscriptGL𝑏ℝ{\bm{Q}}=({\bm{q}}_{1}|\dots|{\bm{q}}_{b})\in\text{GL}_{b}(\mathbb{R}), allowing us to express the inputs 𝑿⊤=𝑸−1​𝑹superscript𝑿topsuperscript𝑸1𝑹{\bm{X}}^{\top}={\bm{Q}}^{-1}{\bm{R}} and activation gradients ∂ℒ∂𝒁=𝑳​𝑸ℒ𝒁𝑳𝑸\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial{\bm{Z}}}={\bm{L}}{\bm{Q}} (Theorem 3.2). Next, we leverages the sparsity of ∂ℒ∂𝒁ℒ𝒁\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial{\bm{Z}}} to recover 𝑸𝑸{\bm{Q}} exactly.

ReLU Induced Sparsity

We show that ReLU layers induce sparse activation gradients ∂ℒ∂𝒁ℒ𝒁\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial{\bm{Z}}} (Section 3.2). We then leverage this sparsity to show that, with high probability, there exist submatrices 𝑳𝑨∈ℝb−1×bsubscript𝑳𝑨superscriptℝ𝑏1𝑏{\bm{L}}_{\bm{A}}\in\mathbb{R}^{b-1\times b} of 𝑳𝑳{\bm{L}}, such that their kernel is an unscaled column 𝒒¯isubscript¯𝒒𝑖\overline{{\bm{q}}}_{i} of our disaggregation matrix 𝑸𝑸{\bm{Q}}, i.e., ker⁡(𝑳𝑨)=span⁡(𝒒i)kernelsubscript𝑳𝑨spansubscript𝒒𝑖\ker({\bm{L}}_{\bm{A}})=\operatorname{span}({\bm{q}}_{i}), for all i∈{1,…,b}𝑖1…𝑏i\in\{1,\dots,b\} (Theorem 3.4). Given these unscaled colmuns 𝒒¯isubscript¯𝒒𝑖\overline{{\bm{q}}}_{i}, we recover their scale by leveraging the bias gradient ∂ℒ∂𝒃ℒ𝒃\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial{\bm{b}}} (Theorem 3.6).

Sampling and Filtering Directions

To identify the submatrices 𝑳𝑨subscript𝑳𝑨{\bm{L}}_{\bm{A}} of 𝑳𝑳{\bm{L}} which induce these directions 𝒒¯isubscript¯𝒒𝑖\overline{{\bm{q}}}_{i}, we propose a sampling-based approach (Section 4.1): We randomly sample b−1𝑏1b-1 rows of 𝑳𝑳{\bm{L}} to obtain an 𝑳𝑨subscript𝑳𝑨{\bm{L}}_{\bm{A}} and thus proposal direction 𝒒¯i′=ker⁡(𝑳𝑨)subscriptsuperscript¯𝒒′𝑖kernelsubscript𝑳𝑨\overline{{\bm{q}}}^{\prime}_{i}=\ker({\bm{L}}_{\bm{A}}) (Figure 2 iii). Crucially, the product 𝑳​𝒒¯i′=∂ℒ∂𝒛i𝑳subscriptsuperscript¯𝒒′𝑖ℒsubscript𝒛𝑖{\bm{L}}\overline{{\bm{q}}}^{\prime}_{i}=\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial{\bm{z}}_{i}} will recover a column of the sparse activation gradient ∂ℒ∂𝒁ℒ𝒁\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial{\bm{Z}}} for correct directions 𝒒¯i′subscriptsuperscript¯𝒒′𝑖\overline{{\bm{q}}}^{\prime}_{i} while incorrect directions will recover a dense linear combination of such columns. This sparsity difference allows us to filter a large number N𝑁N of proposal directions obtained for different submatrices 𝑳𝑨subscript𝑳𝑨{\bm{L}}_{\bm{A}} until c≳bgreater-than-or-equivalent-to𝑐𝑏c\gtrsim b unique candidates remain (Figure 2 iv).

Greedy Direction Selection

We now have to select the correct b𝑏b directions from our set of c𝑐c candidates (Figure 2, v). To this end, we build an initial solution 𝑸′superscript𝑸′{\bm{Q}}^{\prime} from the b𝑏b directions inducing the highest sparsity in ∂ℒ∂𝒁′=𝑳​𝑸′superscriptℒ𝒁′𝑳superscript𝑸′\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial{\bm{Z}}}^{\prime}={\bm{L}}{\bm{Q}}^{\prime}. To assess the quality of this solution 𝑸′superscript𝑸′{\bm{Q}}^{\prime}, we introduce the sparsity matching score σ𝜎\sigma which measures how well the sparsity of the activation gradients ∂ℒ∂𝒁′superscriptℒ𝒁′\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial{\bm{Z}}}^{\prime} matches the ReLU activation pattern induced by the reconstructed input 𝑿′⁣⊤=𝑸′⁣−1​𝑹superscript𝑿′topsuperscript𝑸′1𝑹{\bm{X}}^{\prime\top}={\bm{Q}}^{\prime-1}{\bm{R}}. Finally, we greedily optimize 𝑸′superscript𝑸′{\bm{Q}}^{\prime} to maximize the sparsity matching score, by iteratively replacing an element 𝒒i′subscriptsuperscript𝒒′𝑖{\bm{q}}^{\prime}_{i} of 𝑸′superscript𝑸′{\bm{Q}}^{\prime} with the candidate direction 𝒒j′subscriptsuperscript𝒒′𝑗{\bm{q}}^{\prime}_{j} yielding the greatest improvement in σ𝜎\sigma until convergence. We can then validate the resulting input 𝑿⊤=𝑸−1​𝑹superscript𝑿topsuperscript𝑸1𝑹{\bm{X}}^{\top}={\bm{Q}}^{-1}{\bm{R}} by checking whether it induces the correct gradients.

Algorithm

We formalize this as Algorithm 1 in Section 5 and show that it succeeds with high probability for b<m𝑏𝑚b<m.

3 Gradient Inversion via Sparsity and Low-Rankness

In this Section, we will demonstrate that both low rankness and sparsity arise naturally for gradients of fully connected ReLU networks and explain theoretically how we recover 𝑿𝑿{\bm{X}}. Specifically, in Section 3.1, we first argue that ∂ℒ∂𝑾=∂ℒ∂𝒁​𝑿Tℒ𝑾ℒ𝒁superscript𝑿𝑇\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial{\bm{W}}}=\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial{\bm{Z}}}{\bm{X}}^{T} follows direclty from the chain rule. We then show that for every decomposition ∂ℒ∂𝑾=𝑳​𝑹ℒ𝑾𝑳𝑹\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial{\bm{W}}}={\bm{L}}{\bm{R}}, there exists an unknown disaggregation matrix 𝑸𝑸{\bm{Q}} allowing us to reconstruct 𝑿⊤=𝑸−1​𝑹superscript𝑿topsuperscript𝑸1𝑹{\bm{X}}^{\top}={\bm{Q}}^{-1}{\bm{R}} and ∂ℒ∂𝒁=𝑳​𝑸ℒ𝒁𝑳𝑸\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial{\bm{Z}}}={\bm{L}}{\bm{Q}}. The remainder of our approach then focuses on recovering 𝑸𝑸{\bm{Q}}. To this end, we show in Section 3.2 that ReLU layers induce sparsity in ∂ℒ∂𝒁ℒ𝒁\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial{\bm{Z}}}, which we then leveraged in Section 3.3 to reconstruct the columns of 𝑸𝑸{\bm{Q}} up to scale. Finally, in Section 3.4, we show how the scale of 𝑸𝑸{\bm{Q}}’s columns can be recovered from ∂ℒ∂𝒃ℒ𝒃\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial{\bm{b}}}. Unless otherwise noted, we defer all proofs to App. A.

3.1 Explicit Low-Rank Representation of ∂ℒ∂𝑾ℒ𝑾\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial{\bm{W}}}

We first show that the weight gradients ∂ℒ∂𝑾ℒ𝑾\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial{\bm{W}}} can be written as follows:

Theorem 3.1.

The network’s gradient w.r.t. the weights 𝐖𝐖{\bm{W}} can be represented as the matrix product:

∂ℒ∂𝑾=∂ℒ∂𝒁​𝑿T.ℒ𝑾ℒ𝒁superscript𝑿𝑇\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial{\bm{W}}}=\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial{\bm{Z}}}{\bm{X}}^{T}. (1)

For batch sizes b≤n,m𝑏𝑛𝑚b\leq n,m, the dimensionalities of ∂ℒ∂𝒁∈ℝm×bℒ𝒁superscriptℝ𝑚𝑏\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial{\bm{Z}}}\in\mathbb{R}^{m\times b} and 𝑿∈ℝn×b𝑿superscriptℝ𝑛𝑏{\bm{X}}\in\mathbb{R}^{n\times b} in Equation 1 directly yield that the rank of ∂ℒ∂𝑾ℒ𝑾\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial{\bm{W}}} is at most b𝑏b. This confirms the observations of Kariyappa et al. (2023) and shows that 𝑿𝑿{\bm{X}} and ∂ℒ∂𝒁ℒ𝒁\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial{\bm{Z}}} correspond to a specific low-rank decomposition of ∂ℒ∂𝑾ℒ𝑾\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial{\bm{W}}}.

To actually find this decomposition and thus recover 𝑿𝑿{\bm{X}}, we first consider an arbitrary decomposition of the form ∂ℒ∂𝑾=𝑳​𝑹ℒ𝑾𝑳𝑹\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial{\bm{W}}}={\bm{L}}{\bm{R}}, where 𝑳∈ℝm×b𝑳superscriptℝ𝑚𝑏{\bm{L}}\in\mathbb{R}^{m\times b} and 𝑹∈ℝb×n𝑹superscriptℝ𝑏𝑛{\bm{R}}\in\mathbb{R}^{b\times n} are of maximal rank. We chose the decomposition obtained via the reduced SVD decomposition of ∂ℒ∂𝑾=𝑼​𝑺​𝑽ℒ𝑾𝑼𝑺𝑽\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial{\bm{W}}}={\bm{U}}{\bm{S}}{\bm{V}} by setting 𝑳=𝑼​𝑺12𝑳𝑼superscript𝑺12{\bm{L}}={\bm{U}}{\bm{S}}^{\frac{1}{2}} and 𝑹=𝑺12​𝑽𝑹superscript𝑺12𝑽{\bm{R}}={\bm{S}}^{\frac{1}{2}}{\bm{V}}, where 𝑼∈ℝn×b𝑼superscriptℝ𝑛𝑏{\bm{U}}\in\mathbb{R}^{n\times b}, 𝑺∈ℝb×b𝑺superscriptℝ𝑏𝑏{\bm{S}}\in\mathbb{R}^{b\times b} and 𝑽∈ℝb×n𝑽superscriptℝ𝑏𝑛{\bm{V}}\in\mathbb{R}^{b\times n}.

We now show that there exists an unique disaggregation matrix 𝑸𝑸{\bm{Q}} recovering 𝑿𝑿{\bm{X}} and ∂ℒ∂𝒁ℒ𝒁\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial{\bm{Z}}} from 𝑳𝑳{\bm{L}} and 𝑹𝑹{\bm{R}}:

Theorem 3.2.

If the gradient ∂ℒ∂𝐙ℒ𝐙\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial{\bm{Z}}} and the input matrix 𝐗𝐗{\bm{X}} are of full-rank and b≤n,m𝑏𝑛𝑚b\leq n,m, then there exists an unique matrix 𝐐∈ℝb×b𝐐superscriptℝ𝑏𝑏{\bm{Q}}\in\mathbb{R}^{b\times b} of full-rank s.t.:

∂ℒ∂𝒁ℒ𝒁\displaystyle\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial{\bm{Z}}} =𝑳​𝑸, andabsent𝑳𝑸 and\displaystyle={\bm{L}}{\bm{Q}},\quad\text{ and } (2)
𝑿Tsuperscript𝑿𝑇\displaystyle{\bm{X}}^{T} =𝑸−1​𝑹.absentsuperscript𝑸1𝑹\displaystyle={\bm{Q}}^{-1}{\bm{R}}. (3)

This is a direct consequence of the following lemma:

Lemma 3.3.

Let b,n,m∈ℕ𝑏𝑛𝑚ℕb,n,m\in\mathbb{N} such that b<n,m𝑏𝑛𝑚b<n,m. Further, let 𝐀,𝐋∈ℝm×b𝐀𝐋superscriptℝ𝑚𝑏{\bm{A}},{\bm{L}}\in\mathbb{R}^{m\times b} and 𝐁,𝐑∈ℝb×n𝐁𝐑superscriptℝ𝑏𝑛{\bm{B}},{\bm{R}}\in\mathbb{R}^{b\times n} be matrices of maximal rank, satisfying 𝐀​𝐁=𝐋​𝐑𝐀𝐁𝐋𝐑{\bm{A}}{\bm{B}}={\bm{L}}{\bm{R}}. Then there exists a unique disaggregation matrix 𝐐∈GLb​(ℝ)𝐐subscriptGL𝑏ℝ{\bm{Q}}\in\text{GL}_{b}(\mathbb{R}) s.t. 𝐀=𝐋​𝐐𝐀𝐋𝐐{\bm{A}}={\bm{L}}{\bm{Q}}, and 𝐁=𝐐−1​𝐑𝐁superscript𝐐1𝐑{\bm{B}}={\bm{Q}}^{-1}{\bm{R}}.

Intuitively, Theorem 3.2 states that under most circumstances, reconstructing the input matrix 𝑿𝑿{\bm{X}} and the gradient matrix ∂ℒ∂𝒁ℒ𝒁\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial{\bm{Z}}} is equivalent to recovering the unique disaggregation matrix 𝑸𝑸{\bm{Q}}. We will continue to show how the ReLU-induced sparsity patterns in ∂ℒ∂𝒁ℒ𝒁\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial{\bm{Z}}} or 𝑿𝑿{\bm{X}} can be leveraged to recover 𝑸𝑸{\bm{Q}} exactly.

3.2 ReLU-Induced Sparsity

ReLU activation layers can induce sparsity both in the gradient ∂ℒ∂𝒁ℒ𝒁\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial{\bm{Z}}} (if the ReLU activation succeeds the considered linear layer) or in the input (if the ReLU activation precedes the considered linear layer).

Gradien Sparsity

If a ReLU activation succeeds the linear layer, i.e., 𝒀=ReLU⁡(𝒁)𝒀ReLU𝒁{\bm{Y}}=\operatorname{ReLU}({\bm{Z}}), we have:

∂ℒ∂𝒁=∂ℒ∂𝒀⊙𝟙[𝒁>0],ℒ𝒁direct-productℒ𝒀subscript1delimited-[]𝒁0\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial{\bm{Z}}}=\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial{\bm{Y}}}\odot\mathds{1}_{[{\bm{Z}}>0]}, (4)

where ⊙direct-product\odot is the elementwise multiplication and 𝟙[𝒁>0]subscript1delimited-[]𝒁0\mathds{1}_{[{\bm{Z}}>0]} is a matrix of 00s and 111s with each entry indicating if the corresponding entry in 𝒁𝒁{\bm{Z}} is positive. At initialization, roughly half of the entries in 𝒁𝒁{\bm{Z}} are positive, making ∂ℒ∂𝒁ℒ𝒁\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial{\bm{Z}}} sparse with roughly half the entries being 00.

Input Sparsity

ReLU activations also introduce sparsity if the linear layer in question is preceded by a ReLU activation layer. In this case, 𝑿=ReLU⁡(𝒁~)𝑿ReLU~𝒁{\bm{X}}=\operatorname{ReLU}(\tilde{{\bm{Z}}}) will be sparse with roughly half of its entries being 00s at initialization.

Note that for all but the first and the last layer of a fully connected network, we have sparsity in both, 𝑿𝑿{\bm{X}} and ∂ℒ∂𝒁ℒ𝒁\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial{\bm{Z}}}. Due to the symmetry of Equations 2 and 3, our method can be applied in all three arising sparsity settings. In the remainder of this work, we assume w.l.o.g. that only ∂ℒ∂𝒁ℒ𝒁\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial{\bm{Z}}} is sparse, corresponding to the first layer of a fully connected network. We now describe how to leverage this sparsity to compute the disaggregation matrix 𝑸𝑸{\bm{Q}} and thus recover the input batch 𝑿𝑿{\bm{X}}.

3.3 Breaking Aggregation through Sparsity

Our exact recovery algorithm for the disaggregation matrix 𝑸𝑸{\bm{Q}} is based on the following insight:

If we can construct two submatrices 𝑨∈ℝb−1×b𝑨superscriptℝ𝑏1𝑏{\bm{A}}\in\mathbb{R}^{b-1\times b} and 𝑳A∈ℝb−1×bsubscript𝑳𝐴superscriptℝ𝑏1𝑏{\bm{L}}_{A}\in\mathbb{R}^{b-1\times b} by choosing b−1𝑏1b-1 rows with the same indices from ∂ℒ∂𝒁ℒ𝒁\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial{\bm{Z}}} and 𝑳𝑳{\bm{L}}, respectively, such that 𝑨𝑨{\bm{A}} has full rank and an all-zero ithsuperscript𝑖thi^{\text{th}} column, then the kernel ker⁡(𝑳𝑨)kernelsubscript𝑳𝑨\ker({\bm{L}}_{\bm{A}}) of 𝑳𝑨subscript𝑳𝑨{\bm{L}}_{\bm{A}} contains a column 𝒒isubscript𝒒𝑖{\bm{q}}_{i} of 𝑸𝑸{\bm{Q}} up to scale. We formalize this as follows:

Theorem 3.4.

Let ∂ℒ∂𝐙ℒ𝐙\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial{\bm{Z}}} and 𝐗𝐗{\bm{X}} be of full rank and 𝐀∈ℝb−1×b𝐀superscriptℝ𝑏1𝑏{\bm{A}}\in\mathbb{R}^{b-1\times b} a submatrix of ∂ℒ∂𝐙ℒ𝐙\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial{\bm{Z}}} of full rank such that the ithsuperscript𝑖thi^{\text{th}} column is 𝟎0\mathbf{0} for some i∈{1,…,b}𝑖1…𝑏i\in\{1,\dots,b\}. Further let 𝐐𝐐{\bm{Q}} be as in Theorem 3.2. Then, there exists a full-rank submatrix 𝐋A∈ℝb−1×bsubscript𝐋𝐴superscriptℝ𝑏1𝑏{\bm{L}}_{A}\in\mathbb{R}^{b-1\times b} of 𝐋𝐋{\bm{L}} such that span⁡(𝐪i)=ker⁡(𝐋A)spansubscript𝐪𝑖kernelsubscript𝐋𝐴\operatorname{span}({\bm{q}}_{i})=\ker({\bm{L}}_{A}) for the ithsuperscript𝑖thi^{\text{th}} column 𝐪isubscript𝐪𝑖{\bm{q}}_{i} of 𝐐=(𝐪1​|⋯|​𝐪b)𝐐subscript𝐪1⋯subscript𝐪𝑏{\bm{Q}}=({\bm{q}}_{1}|\cdots|{\bm{q}}_{b}).

Proof.

Pick an i∈{1,…,b}𝑖1…𝑏i\in\{1,\dots,b\}. By assumption, there exists a submatrix 𝑨∈ℝb−1×b𝑨superscriptℝ𝑏1𝑏{\bm{A}}\in\mathbb{R}^{b-1\times b} of ∂ℒ∂𝒁ℒ𝒁\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial{\bm{Z}}} of rank b−1𝑏1b-1 such that the ithsuperscript𝑖thi^{\text{th}} column is 𝟎0\mathbf{0}. Now, we construct 𝑳𝑨subscript𝑳𝑨{\bm{L}}_{\bm{A}} by taking the rows from 𝑳𝑳{\bm{L}} with the same indices as the rows of 𝑨𝑨{\bm{A}} have in ∂ℒ∂𝒁ℒ𝒁\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial{\bm{Z}}}.

As ∂ℒ∂𝒁ℒ𝒁\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial{\bm{Z}}} and 𝑿𝑿{\bm{X}} have full rank, by Theorem 3.2, we know that ∂ℒ∂𝒁=𝑳​𝑸ℒ𝒁𝑳𝑸\tfrac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial{\bm{Z}}}={\bm{L}}{\bm{Q}}, and hence 𝑨=𝑳𝑨​𝑸𝑨subscript𝑳𝑨𝑸{\bm{A}}={\bm{L}}_{\bm{A}}{\bm{Q}}. Multiplying from the right with 𝒆isubscript𝒆𝑖{\bm{e}}_{i} yields

0=𝑨​𝒆i=𝑳𝑨​𝑸​𝒆i=𝑳𝑨​𝒒i,0𝑨subscript𝒆𝑖subscript𝑳𝑨𝑸subscript𝒆𝑖subscript𝑳𝑨subscript𝒒𝑖0={\bm{A}}{\bm{e}}_{i}={\bm{L}}_{\bm{A}}{\bm{Q}}{\bm{e}}_{i}={\bm{L}}_{\bm{A}}{\bm{q}}_{i},

and hence ker⁡(𝑳𝑨)⊇span⁡(𝒒i)spansubscript𝒒𝑖kernelsubscript𝑳𝑨\ker({\bm{L}}_{\bm{A}})\supseteq\operatorname{span}({\bm{q}}_{i}). Further, as rank⁡(𝑨)=b−1rank𝑨𝑏1\operatorname{rank}({\bm{A}})=b-1 and rank⁡(𝑸)=brank𝑸𝑏\operatorname{rank}({\bm{Q}})=b, we have that rank⁡(𝑳𝑨)=b−1ranksubscript𝑳𝑨𝑏1\operatorname{rank}({\bm{L}}_{\bm{A}})=b-1. With the rank-nullity theorem we see that dim(ker⁡(𝑳𝑨))=1dimensionkernelsubscript𝑳𝑨1\dim(\ker({\bm{L}}_{\bm{A}}))=1 and hence ker⁡(𝑳𝑨)=span⁡(𝒒i)kernelsubscript𝑳𝑨spansubscript𝒒𝑖\ker({\bm{L}}_{\bm{A}})=\operatorname{span}({\bm{q}}_{i}). ∎

As ∂ℒ∂𝒁ℒ𝒁\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial{\bm{Z}}} is not known a priori, we can not simply search for such a set of rows. Instead, we have to sample submatrices 𝑳𝑨subscript𝑳𝑨{\bm{L}}_{\bm{A}} of 𝑳𝑳{\bm{L}} at random and then filter them using the approach discussed in Section 4. However, we will show in Section 5.2 that we will find suitable submatrices with high probability for b<m𝑏𝑚b<m due to the sparsity of ∂ℒ∂𝒁ℒ𝒁\tfrac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial{\bm{Z}}} and the large number (mb−1)binomial𝑚𝑏1\binom{m}{b-1} of possible submatrices.

We will now discuss how to recover the scale of the columns 𝒒isubscript𝒒𝑖{\bm{q}}_{i} given their unscaled directions 𝒒¯isubscript¯𝒒𝑖\overline{{\bm{q}}}_{i} forming 𝑸¯¯𝑸\overline{{\bm{Q}}}.

3.4 Obtaining 𝑸𝑸{\bm{Q}}: Recovering the Scale of columns in 𝑸¯¯𝑸\overline{{\bm{Q}}}

Given a set of b𝑏b correct directions 𝑸¯=(𝒒1¯​|⋯|​𝒒b¯)¯𝑸¯subscript𝒒1⋯¯subscript𝒒𝑏\overline{{\bm{Q}}}=(\overline{{\bm{q}}_{1}}|\cdots|\overline{{\bm{q}}_{b}}), we can recover their scale, enabling us to reconstruct 𝑿𝑿{\bm{X}}, as follows.

We first represent the correctly scaled columns as 𝒒i=ci⋅𝒒i¯subscript𝒒𝑖⋅subscript𝑐𝑖¯subscript𝒒𝑖{\bm{q}}_{i}=c_{i}\cdot\overline{{\bm{q}}_{i}} with the unknown scale parameters ci∈ℝsubscript𝑐𝑖ℝc_{i}\in\mathbb{R}. Now, recovering the scale is equivalent to computing all cisubscript𝑐𝑖c_{i}. To this end, we leverage the gradient w.r.t. the bias ∂ℒ∂𝒃ℒ𝒃\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial{\bm{b}}}:

Lemma 3.5.

The gradient w.r.t. the bias 𝐛𝐛{\bm{b}} can be written in the form:

∂ℒ∂𝒃=∂ℒ∂𝒁​[1⋮1].ℒ𝒃ℒ𝒁matrix1⋮1\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial{\bm{b}}}=\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial{\bm{Z}}}\begin{bmatrix}1\\ \vphantom{\int\limits^{x}}\smash{\vdots}\\ 1\end{bmatrix}. (5)

Thus, the coefficients cisubscript𝑐𝑖c_{i} can be calculated as:

Theorem 3.6.

For any left inverse 𝐋−Lsuperscript𝐋𝐿{\bm{L}}^{-L} of 𝐋𝐋{\bm{L}}, we have:

[c1⋮cb]=𝑸¯−1​𝑳−L​∂ℒ∂𝒃matrixsubscript𝑐1⋮subscript𝑐𝑏superscript¯𝑸1superscript𝑳𝐿ℒ𝒃\begin{bmatrix}c_{1}\\ \vphantom{\int\limits^{x}}\smash{\vdots}\\ c_{b}\end{bmatrix}=\overline{{\bm{Q}}}\,^{-1}{\bm{L}}^{-L}\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial{\bm{b}}} (6)

Once we have computed the unscaled 𝑸¯¯𝑸\overline{{\bm{Q}}}, we can directly obtain the disaggregation matrix 𝑸=𝑸¯​diag⁡(c1,…,cb)𝑸¯𝑸diagsubscript𝑐1…subscript𝑐𝑏{\bm{Q}}=\overline{{\bm{Q}}}\operatorname{diag}(c_{1},\ldots,c_{b}) allowing us to reconstruct the input 𝑿⊤=𝑸−1​𝑹superscript𝑿topsuperscript𝑸1𝑹{\bm{X}}^{\top}={\bm{Q}}^{-1}{\bm{R}}. We now discuss how to sample and filter candidate directions 𝒒¯isubscript¯𝒒𝑖\overline{{\bm{q}}}_{i} to recover 𝑸¯¯𝑸\overline{{\bm{Q}}}.

4 Efficient Filtering and Validation of Candidates

In the previous section, we saw that given the correct selection of submatrices 𝑳𝑨subscript𝑳𝑨{\bm{L}}_{\bm{A}}, we can recover 𝑸𝑸{\bm{Q}} directly. However, we do not know how to pick 𝑳𝑨subscript𝑳𝑨{\bm{L}}_{\bm{A}} a priori. To solve this problem, we rely on a sampling-based approach: We first randomly sample submatrices 𝑳𝑨subscript𝑳𝑨{\bm{L}}_{\bm{A}} of 𝑳𝑳{\bm{L}} and corresponding direction candidates 𝒒¯′superscript¯𝒒′\overline{{\bm{q}}}^{\prime} spanning ker⁡(𝑳𝑨)kernelsubscript𝑳𝑨\ker({\bm{L}}_{\bm{A}}). However, checking whether 𝒒¯′superscript¯𝒒′\overline{{\bm{q}}}^{\prime} is a valid direction is not straightforward as we do not know ∂ℒ∂𝒁ℒ𝒁\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial{\bm{Z}}} and hence can not observe 𝑨𝑨{\bm{A}} directly as reconstructing ∂ℒ∂𝒁=𝑳​𝑸ℒ𝒁𝑳𝑸\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial{\bm{Z}}}={\bm{L}}{\bm{Q}} requires the full 𝑸𝑸{\bm{Q}}.

To address this, we propose a method to filter the majority of wrong proposals 𝒒¯′superscript¯𝒒′\overline{{\bm{q}}}^{\prime} using deduplication and a sparsity-based criterion (discussed in Section 4.1). This leaves us with a set of candidate directions 𝒞={𝒒¯j′}j∈{1,…,c}𝒞subscriptsuperscriptsubscript¯𝒒𝑗′𝑗1…𝑐\mathcal{C}=\{\overline{{\bm{q}}}_{j}^{\prime}\}_{j\in\{1,\dots,c\}}, among which we then select the correct directions by greedily optimizing a novel sparsity matching score (discussed in Section 4.2).

4.1 Efficient Filtering of Directions 𝒒¯′superscript¯𝒒′\overline{{\bm{q}}}^{\prime}

Filtering Mixtures via Sparsity

It is highly likely (p=(1−12b−1)b𝑝superscript11superscript2𝑏1𝑏p=(1-\tfrac{1}{2^{b-1}})^{b}) that a random submatrix of 𝑳𝑳{\bm{L}} will not correspond to an 𝑨𝑨{\bm{A}} with any 𝟎0\mathbf{0} column. We filter these directions by leveraging the following insight. The kernel of such submatrices is spanned by a linear combination 𝒒¯′=∑iαi​𝒒¯isuperscript¯𝒒′subscript𝑖subscript𝛼𝑖subscript¯𝒒𝑖\overline{{\bm{q}}}^{\prime}=\sum_{i}\alpha_{i}\overline{{\bm{q}}}_{i}. Thus 𝑳​𝒒¯′𝑳superscript¯𝒒′{\bm{L}}\overline{{\bm{q}}}^{\prime} will be a linear combination of sparse columns of ∂𝓛∂𝒁𝓛𝒁\frac{\partial\mathcal{{\bm{L}}}}{\partial{\bm{Z}}}. As this sparsity structure is random, linear combinations will have much lower sparsity with high probability. We thus discard all candidates 𝒒¯′superscript¯𝒒′\overline{{\bm{q}}}^{\prime} with sparsity of 𝑳​𝒒¯′𝑳superscript¯𝒒′{\bm{L}}\overline{{\bm{q}}}^{\prime} below a threshold τ𝜏\tau, chosen to make the probability of falsely rejecting a correct direction pf​r​(τ,m)=12m​∑i=0⌊m⋅τ⌋(mi)subscript𝑝𝑓𝑟𝜏𝑚1superscript2𝑚superscriptsubscript𝑖0⋅𝑚𝜏binomial𝑚𝑖p_{fr}(\tau,m)=\frac{1}{2^{m}}\sum_{i=0}^{\lfloor m\cdot\tau\rfloor}\binom{m}{i}, obtained from the cumulative distribution function of the binomial distribution, small. For example for m=400𝑚400m=400 and pf​r​(τ,m)<10−5subscript𝑝𝑓𝑟𝜏𝑚superscript105p_{fr}(\tau,m)<10^{-5}, we have τ=0.395𝜏0.395\tau=0.395. We obtain the candidate pool 𝒞={𝒒¯j′}j∈{1,…,c}𝒞subscriptsuperscriptsubscript¯𝒒𝑗′𝑗1…𝑐\mathcal{C}=\{\overline{{\bm{q}}}_{j}^{\prime}\}_{j\in\{1,\dots,c\}} from all samples that were not filered this way.

Filtering Duplicates

As it is highly likely to have multiple full-rank submatrices 𝑨𝑨{\bm{A}}, whose ithsuperscript𝑖thi^{\text{th}} column is 𝟎0\mathbf{0}, we expect to sample the same proposal 𝒒¯i′superscriptsubscript¯𝒒𝑖′\overline{{\bm{q}}}_{i}^{\prime} multiple times. We remove these duplicates substantially reduces our search space.

4.2 Greedy Optimization

While filtering duplicates and linear combinations significantly reduces the number c𝑐c of candidates, we usually still have to select a subset of b<c𝑏𝑐b<c. Thus, we have (cb)binomial𝑐𝑏\binom{c}{b} possible b𝑏b sized subsets, each inducing a candidate 𝑸′superscript𝑸′{\bm{Q}}^{\prime} and thus 𝑿′superscript𝑿′{\bm{X}}^{\prime}. A naive approach would be to compute the gradients for all 𝑿′superscript𝑿′{\bm{X}}^{\prime} and compare them against the ground truth. However, this is computationally intractable even for moderate candidate numbers c𝑐c.

To address this, we propose a greedy two-stage procedure optimizing a novel sparsity matching score σ𝜎\sigma, solely relying on ∂ℒ∂𝒁′superscriptℒ𝒁′\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial{\bm{Z}}}^{\prime} and 𝒁′superscript𝒁′{\bm{Z}}^{\prime}. As both can be computed directly via 𝑸′superscript𝑸′{\bm{Q}}^{\prime}, the procedure is local, does not need to backpropagate gradients and resolves the computational complexity issue mentioned at the beginning of this subsection while also accurately selecting the correct batch elements. Next, we explain the first stage.

Dictionary Learning (Spielman et al., 2012)

As a first stage, we leverage a component of the algorithm proposed by Spielman et al. (2012) for sparsely-used dictionary learning. This approach is based on the insight that the subset of column vectors {𝒒¯i′}i=1bsuperscriptsubscriptsuperscriptsubscript¯𝒒𝑖′𝑖1𝑏\{\overline{{\bm{q}}}_{i}^{\prime}\}_{i=1}^{b}, yielding the sparsest full-rank gradient matrix ∂L∂𝒁𝐿𝒁\frac{\partial L}{\partial{\bm{Z}}} via Equation 2 is often correct. As the scaling of 𝒒¯i′superscriptsubscript¯𝒒𝑖′\overline{{\bm{q}}}_{i}^{\prime} does not change the sparsity in Equation 2, we can construct this subset ℬℬ\mathcal{B} by greedily collecting the b𝑏b directions 𝒒¯i′superscriptsubscript¯𝒒𝑖′\overline{{\bm{q}}}_{i}^{\prime} with the highest corresponding sparsity that still increases the rank of ℬℬ\mathcal{B}. While this approach typically recovers most directions 𝒒¯isubscript¯𝒒𝑖\overline{{\bm{q}}}_{i}, it often misses directions whose gradients ∂L∂𝒛i𝐿subscript𝒛𝑖\frac{\partial L}{\partial{\bm{z}}_{i}} are less sparse by chance.

Sparsity Matching

We alleviate this issue by introducing a second stage to the algorithm where we greedily optimize a novel correctness measure based solely on the gradients of the linear layer, which we call the sparsity matching coefficient σ𝜎\sigma.

Definition 4.1.

Let σ−subscript𝜎\sigma_{-} be the number of non-positive entries in 𝒁𝒁{\bm{Z}} whose corresponding entries in ∂ℒ∂𝒁ℒ𝒁\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial{\bm{Z}}} are 00. Similarly, let σ+subscript𝜎\sigma_{+} be the number of positive entries in 𝒁𝒁{\bm{Z}} whose corresponding entries in ∂ℒ∂𝒁ℒ𝒁\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial{\bm{Z}}} are not 00. We call their normalized sum the sparsity matching coefficient σ𝜎\sigma:

σ=σ−+σ+m⋅b.𝜎subscript𝜎subscript𝜎⋅𝑚𝑏\sigma=\frac{\sigma_{-}+\sigma_{+}}{m\cdot b}.

Intuitively, this describes how well the pre-activation values 𝒁𝒁{\bm{Z}} match the sparsity pattern of the gradients ∂ℒ∂𝒁ℒ𝒁\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial{\bm{Z}}}, induced by the succeeding ReLU layer 𝒀=ReLU⁡(𝒁)𝒀ReLU𝒁{\bm{Y}}=\operatorname{ReLU}({\bm{Z}}), as shown in Equation 4.

While this sparsity matching coefficient σ𝜎\sigma can take values between 00 and 111, it is exactly σ=1𝜎1\sigma=1 for the correct 𝑿𝑿{\bm{X}}, if the gradient ∂ℒ∂𝒀ℒ𝒀\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial{\bm{Y}}} w.r.t. the ReLU output is dense, which is usually the case. We note that σ𝜎\sigma can be computed efficiently for arbitrary full rank matrix 𝑸¯′superscript¯𝑸′\overline{{\bm{Q}}}^{\prime} by computing ∂ℒ∂𝒁′=𝑳​𝑸′superscriptℒ𝒁′𝑳superscript𝑸′\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial{\bm{Z}}}^{\prime}={\bm{L}}{\bm{Q}}^{\prime} and 𝒁′=𝑾​𝑿′+(𝒃​|…|​𝒃)superscript𝒁′𝑾superscript𝑿′𝒃…𝒃{\bm{Z}}^{\prime}={\bm{W}}{\bm{X}}^{\prime}+({\bm{b}}|\dots|{\bm{b}}) for 𝑿′⁣⊤=𝑸′⁣−1​𝑹superscript𝑿′topsuperscript𝑸′1𝑹{\bm{X}}^{\prime\top}={\bm{Q}}^{\prime-1}{\bm{R}}.

To optimize σ𝜎\sigma, we initialize 𝑸¯′superscript¯𝑸′\overline{{\bm{Q}}}^{\prime} with the result of the greedy algorithm in Spielman et al. (2012), and then greedily swap the pair of vectors 𝒒¯i′subscriptsuperscript¯𝒒′𝑖\overline{{\bm{q}}}^{\prime}_{i} that improves σ𝜎\sigma the most, while not changing the rank, until convergence.

5 Final Algorithm and Complexity Analysis

In this section, we first present our final algorithm SPEAR (Section 5.1) and then analyse its expected complexity and failure probability (Section 5.2).

5.1 Final Algorithm

We formalize our gradient inversion attack SPEAR in Algorithm 1 and outline it below. First, we compute the low-rank decomposition ∂ℒ∂𝑾=𝑳​𝑹ℒ𝑾𝑳𝑹\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial{\bm{W}}}={\bm{L}}{\bm{R}} of the weight gradient ∂ℒ∂𝑾ℒ𝑾\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial{\bm{W}}} via reduced SVD, allowing us to recover the batch size b𝑏b as the rank of ∂ℒ∂𝑾ℒ𝑾\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial{\bm{W}}} (Line 2). We now sample (at most N𝑁N) submatrices 𝑳𝑨subscript𝑳𝑨{\bm{L}}_{\bm{A}} of 𝑳𝑳{\bm{L}} and compute proposal directions 𝒒¯i′superscriptsubscript¯𝒒𝑖′\overline{{\bm{q}}}_{i}^{\prime} as their kernel ker⁡(𝑳𝑨)kernelsubscript𝑳𝑨\ker({\bm{L}}_{\bm{A}}) via SVD (Lines 4 and 5). We note that our implementation parallelizes both sampling and SVD computation (Lines 4 and 5) on a GPU. We then filter the proposal directions 𝒒¯i′superscriptsubscript¯𝒒𝑖′\overline{{\bm{q}}}_{i}^{\prime} based on their sparsity (Line 6), adding them to our candidate pool 𝒞𝒞\mathcal{C} if they haven’t been recovered already and are sufficiently sparse (Line 7). Once our candidate pool contains at least b𝑏b directions, we begin constructing candidate input reconstructions 𝑿′superscript𝑿′{\bm{X}}^{\prime} using our two-stage greedy algorithm GreedyFilter (Line 8), discussed in Section 4.2. If this reconstruction leads to a solution with sparsity matching coefficient σ=1𝜎1\sigma=1, we terminate early and return the corresponding candidate solution (Line 9). Otherwise, we continue sampling until we have reached N𝑁N samples and return the best reconstruction we can obtain from the resulting candidate pool (Line 11). The pseudocode for ComputeSigma (Algorithm 2) and GreedyFilter (Algorithm 3) are deferred to App. B.

5.2 Analysis

In this section, we will analyze SPEAR w.r.t. the number of submatrices we expect to sample until we have recovered all b𝑏b correct directions 𝒒¯isubscript¯𝒒𝑖\overline{{\bm{q}}}_{i} (Lemma 5.2), and the probability of failing to recover all b𝑏b correct directions despite checking all possible submatrices of 𝑳𝑳{\bm{L}} (Lemma 5.3). For an analysis of the number of submatrices we have to sample until we have recovered all b𝑏b correct directions 𝒒¯isubscript¯𝒒𝑖\overline{{\bm{q}}}_{i} with high probability, we point to Lemma A.1. Further, as before, we defer all proofs also to App. A.

Expected Number of Required Samples

To determine the expected number of required samples until we have recovered the correct b𝑏b direction vectors 𝒒¯isubscript¯𝒒𝑖\overline{{\bm{q}}}_{i}, we first compute a lower bound on the probability q𝑞q of sampling a submatrix which satisfies the conditions of Theorem 3.4 for an arbitrary column i𝑖i in 𝑸¯¯𝑸\overline{{\bm{Q}}} and then use the coupon collector problem to compute the expected number of required samples.

We can lower bound the probability of a submatrix 𝑨∈ℝb−1×b𝑨superscriptℝ𝑏1𝑏{\bm{A}}\in\mathbb{R}^{b-1\times b}, randomly sampled as b−1𝑏1b-1 rows of ∂ℒ∂𝒁ℒ𝒁\tfrac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial{\bm{Z}}}, having exactly one all-zero column and being full rank as follows:

Lemma 5.1.

Let 𝐀∈ℝb−1×b𝐀superscriptℝ𝑏1𝑏{\bm{A}}\in\mathbb{R}^{b-1\times b} be submatrix of the gradient ∂ℒ∂𝐙ℒ𝐙\tfrac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial{\bm{Z}}} obtained by sampling b−1𝑏1b-1 rows uniformly at random without replacement, where each element of ∂ℒ∂𝐙ℒ𝐙\tfrac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial{\bm{Z}}} is distributed i.i.d. as ∂ℒ∂𝐙j,k=ζ​|ϵ|ℒsubscript𝐙𝑗𝑘𝜁italic-ϵ\tfrac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial{\bm{Z}}_{j,k}}=\zeta|\epsilon| with ϵ∼𝒩​(μ=0,σ2>0)similar-toitalic-ϵ𝒩formulae-sequence𝜇0superscript𝜎20\epsilon\sim\mathcal{N}(\mu=0,\sigma^{2}>0) and ζ∼Bernoulli​(p=12)similar-to𝜁Bernoulli𝑝12\zeta\sim\text{Bernoulli}(p=\tfrac{1}{2}). We then have the probability q𝑞q of 𝐀𝐀{\bm{A}} having exactly one all-zero column and being full rank lower bounded by:

q𝑞\displaystyle q ≥b2b−1​(1−(12+ob−1​(1))b−1)absent𝑏superscript2𝑏11superscript12subscript𝑜𝑏11𝑏1\displaystyle\geq\frac{b}{2^{b-1}}\left(1-(\tfrac{1}{2}+o_{b-1}(1))^{b-1}\right)
≥b2b−1​(1−0.939b−1).absent𝑏superscript2𝑏11superscript0.939𝑏1\displaystyle\geq\frac{b}{2^{b-1}}(1-0.939^{b-1}).

We can now compute the expected number of submatrices ntotal∗subscriptsuperscript𝑛totaln^{*}_{\text{total}} we have to draw until we have recovered all b𝑏b correct direction vectors using the Coupon Collector Problem:

Lemma 5.2.

Assuming i.i.d. submatrices 𝐀𝐀{\bm{A}} following the distribution outlined in Lemma 5.1 and using Algorithm 1, we have the expected number of submatrices ntotal∗subscriptsuperscript𝑛totaln^{*}_{\text{total}} required to recover all b𝑏b correct direction vectors as:

ntotal∗=1q​∑k=0b−1bb−k=b​Hbq≈1q​(b​log⁡(b)+γ​b+12),subscriptsuperscript𝑛total1𝑞superscriptsubscript𝑘0𝑏1𝑏𝑏𝑘𝑏subscript𝐻𝑏𝑞1𝑞𝑏𝑏𝛾𝑏12n^{*}_{\text{total}}=\frac{1}{q}\sum_{k=0}^{b-1}\frac{b}{b-k}=\frac{bH_{b}}{q}\approx\frac{1}{q}(b\log(b)+\gamma b+\tfrac{1}{2}),

where Hbsubscript𝐻𝑏H_{b} is the bthsuperscript𝑏thb^{\text{th}} harmonic number and γ≈0.57722𝛾0.57722\gamma\approx 0.57722 the Euler-Mascheroni constant.

We validate this result experimentally in Figure 4 where we observe excellent agreement for wide networks (m≫bmuch-greater-than𝑚𝑏m\gg b) and obtain, e.g., ntotal∗≈1.8×105subscriptsuperscript𝑛total1.8superscript105n^{*}_{\text{total}}\approx 1.8\times 10^{5} for a batch size of b=16𝑏16b=16.

Failure Probability

We now analyze the probability of SPEAR failing despite considering all possible submatrices of 𝑳𝑳{\bm{L}} and obtain:

Lemma 5.3.

Under the same assumptions as in Lemma 5.1, we have an upper bound on the failure probability pfailubsuperscriptsubscript𝑝failubp_{\text{fail}}^{\text{ub}} of Algorithm 1 even when sampling exhaustively as:

pfailub≤b​(1−∑k=b−1m(mk)​12m​(1−0.939(b−1)​(kb−1)))+1−(1−pf​r)b,superscriptsubscript𝑝failub𝑏1superscriptsubscript𝑘𝑏1𝑚binomial𝑚𝑘1superscript2𝑚1superscript0.939𝑏1binomial𝑘𝑏11superscript1subscript𝑝𝑓𝑟𝑏p_{\text{fail}}^{\text{ub}}\leq b\left(1-\sum_{k=b-1}^{m}\binom{m}{k}\frac{1}{2^{m}}\left(1-0.939^{(b-1)\binom{k}{b-1}}\right)\right)\\ +1-(1-p_{fr})^{b},

where pf​rsubscript𝑝𝑓𝑟p_{fr} is the probability of a correct direction vector being falsely rejected by our sparsity filter (Section 4.1).

If we assume the full-rankness of submatrices 𝑨𝑨{\bm{A}} to i) occur with probability 1−(12−ob−1​(1))b−11superscript12subscript𝑜𝑏11𝑏11-(\frac{1}{2}-o_{b-1}(1))^{b-1} for ob−1​(1)≈0subscript𝑜𝑏110o_{b-1}(1)\approx 0 (true for large b𝑏b (Tikhomirov, 2020)) and ii) be independent between submatrices, we instead obtain:

pfailapprox≈1−(∑k=b−1m(mk)​12m​(1−0.5(b−1)​(kb−1)))b+1−(1−pf​r)b.superscriptsubscript𝑝failapprox1superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑘𝑏1𝑚binomial𝑚𝑘1superscript2𝑚1superscript0.5𝑏1binomial𝑘𝑏1𝑏1superscript1subscript𝑝𝑓𝑟𝑏p_{\text{fail}}^{\text{approx}}\approx 1-\left(\sum_{k=b-1}^{m}\binom{m}{k}\frac{1}{2^{m}}\left(1-0.5^{(b-1)\binom{k}{b-1}}\right)\right)^{b}\\ +1-(1-p_{fr})^{b}.\vspace{-5mm}

We illustrate this bound in Figure 3 and empirically validate this bound in Figure 8 and observe the true failure probability to lie between pfailapproxsuperscriptsubscript𝑝failapproxp_{\text{fail}}^{\text{approx}} and pfailubsuperscriptsubscript𝑝failubp_{\text{fail}}^{\text{ub}}.

6 Empirical Evaluation

In this section, we empirically evaluate the effectiveness of SPEAR on MNIST (LeCun et al., 2010), CIFAR-10 (Krizhevsky et al., 2009), and TinyImageNet (Le & Yang, 2015) across a wide range of settings. In addition to the reconstruction quality metrics PSNR, SSIM, MSE, and LPIPS, commonly used to evaluate gradient inversion attacks, we report accuracy as the portion of batches for which we recovered all batch elements exactly (up to numerical errors) and the number of sampled submatrices (number of iterations).

Experimental Setup

For all reported experiments, we use our highly parallelized PyTorch-based (Paszke et al., 2019) GPU implementation of SPEAR. Unless indicated otherwise, we run all of our experiments with a batch size of b=20𝑏20b=20 CIFAR-10 images using a 666 layer fully-connected ReLU network with a width of m=200𝑚200m=200 and choose τ𝜏\tau to achieve a false rejection rate of pf​r≤10−5subscript𝑝𝑓𝑟superscript105p_{fr}\leq 10^{-5}.

6.1 Main Results

We evaluate SPEAR on MNIST, CIFAR-10, and TinyImageNet, reporting results in Table 1. Across datasets, SPEAR can reconstruct almost all batches perfectly, achieving PSNRs of 100100100 and above even at a batch size of b=20𝑏20b=20. As these results indicate a significantly better reconstruction than any other method applicable to batch sizes b>1𝑏1b>1, we omit a detailed quantitative comparison to prior work.

6.2 Ablation Studies

Effect of Batch Size b𝑏b

We evaluate the effect of batch size b𝑏b on accuracy and the required number of iterations ntotal∗subscriptsuperscript𝑛totaln^{*}_{\text{total}} for a wide (m=2000𝑚2000m=2000) and narrow (m=200𝑚200m=200) network. While ntotal∗subscriptsuperscript𝑛totaln^{*}_{\text{total}} increases exponentially with b𝑏b, for both networks, the narrower network requires about 202020 times more iterations than the wider network (see Figure 4). While trends for the wider network (m≫bmuch-greater-than𝑚𝑏m\gg b) are perfectly described by our theoretical results in Section 5.2, some independence assumptions are violated for the narrower network, explaining the larger number of required iterations. While we can recover all batches perfectly for the wider network, we see a sharp drop in accuracy from 99%percent9999\% at b=20𝑏20b=20 to 63%percent6363\% at b=24𝑏24b=24 (see Figure 6) for the narrower network. This is due to increasingly more batches requiring more than the N=2×109𝑁2superscript109N=2\times 10^{9} submatrices we sample at most.

Effect of Network Architecture

We visualize the performance of SPEAR across different network widths and depths in Figure 5. We observe that while accuracy is independent of both (given sufficient width m≫bmuch-greater-than𝑚𝑏m\gg b), the number of required iterations reduces with increasing width m𝑚m.

Effectivness of our 2-Stage Greedy Algorithm

We compare reconstruction success rate (accuracy) with and without the second stage of our greedy algorithm discussed in Section 4.2 in Figure 6. We observe that this second stage becomes increasingly important for larger batch size b𝑏b.

Effect of Network Training

We train a network on MNIST and evaluate SPEAR periodically during training, visualizing results in Figure 7. We observe that generally SPEAR performs very well on trained networks, with the number of required steps as on untrained networks. However, if the minimum column sparsity of ∂ℒ∂𝒁ℒ𝒁\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial{\bm{Z}}} drops significantly as is the case for the checkpoints after 2000 and 3000 steps in the illustrated run performance drops slightly.

Failure Probabilities

We validate our theoretical results on SPEAR’s failure rate (Lemma 5.3) in Figure 8. As this requires exhaustive sampling of all (mb−1)binomial𝑚𝑏1\binom{m}{b-1} submatrices of 𝑳𝑳{\bm{L}} we only consider small batch sizes b≤10𝑏10b\leq 10 and networks m≤40𝑚40m\leq 40. We observe that the empirical failure probability (blue) with 95%percent9595\% Clopper-Pearson confidence bounds lies between the analytical upper bound (dashed line) and approximation (solid line). We conclude that in most settings, the number of required samples rather than complete failure is the limiting factor for SPEAR’s performance.

7 Related Work

In this section, we discuss how we relate to prior work.

Gradient Inversion Attacks

Since gradient inversion attacks have been introduced (Zhu et al., 2019), two settings have emerged: In the malicious setting, the server does not adhere to the training protocol and can adversarially engineer network weights that maximize leaked information (Boenisch et al., 2021; Fowl et al., 2022b; a; Wen et al., 2022). In the strictly harder honest-but-curious setting, the server follows the training protocol but still aims to reconstruct client data. We target the honest-but-curious setting, where prior work has either recovered the input exactly for batch sizes of b=1𝑏1b=1 (Phong et al., 2018; Zhu & Blaschko, 2021), or approximately for b>1𝑏1b>1 Geiping et al. (2020); Yin et al. (2021); Geng et al. (2021); Vero et al. (2022); Kariyappa et al. (2023). In this setting, we are the first to reconstruct inputs exactly for batch sizes b>1𝑏1b>1.

Most closely related to our work is Kariyappa et al. (2023) which leverage the low-rank structure of the gradients to frame gradient inversion as a blind source separation problem, improving their approximate reconstructions. In contrast, we derive an explicit low-rank representation and additionally leverage gradient sparsity reconstruct inputs exactly.

Unlike a long line of prior work, we rely neither on any priors on the data distribution (Vero et al., 2022; Balunović et al., 2022a; Gupta et al., 2022; Li et al., 2022) nor on a reconstructed classification label Geiping et al. (2020); Zhao et al. (2020); Geng et al. (2021); Yin et al. (2021); Vero et al. (2022). This allows our approach to be employed in a much wider range of settings where neither is available.

Defenses Against Gradient Inversion

Defenses based on Differential Privacy (Abadi et al., 2016) add noise to the computed gradients on the client side, providing provable privacy guarantees at the cost of significantly reduced utility. Another line of work increases the empirical difficulty of inversion by increasing the effective batch size, by securely aggregating gradients from multiple clients (Bonawitz et al., 2016) or doing multiple gradient update steps locally before sharing an aggregated weight update (Dimitrov et al., 2022). Finally, different heuristic defenses such as gradient pruning (Zhu et al., 2019) have been proposed, although their effectiveness has been questioned (Balunović et al., 2022b).

Sparsely used Dictionary learning

Recovering the disaggregation matrix 𝑸𝑸{\bm{Q}} is related to the well-studied problem of sparsely-used dictionary learning. However, there the aim is to find the sparsest coefficient matrix (corresponding to our ∂ℒ∂𝒁ℒ𝒁\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial{\bm{Z}}}) and dense dictionary (𝑸−1superscript𝑸1{\bm{Q}}^{-1}) encoding a given signal (𝑳𝑳{\bm{L}}) up to some error. In contrast, we do not search for the sparsest solution yielding an approximate reconstruction but a solution that exactly induces consistent 𝑿𝑿{\bm{X}} and ∂ℒ∂𝒁ℒ𝒁\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial{\bm{Z}}}, which happens to be sparse.

Generally, sparsely-used dictionary learning is known to be NP-hard (Tillmann, 2014) and typically solved approximately (Aharon et al., 2006; Spielman et al., 2012; Sun et al., 2016). However, in specific cases, it can be solved exactly in polynomial time (Spielman et al., 2012). While ∂ℒ∂𝒁ℒ𝒁\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial{\bm{Z}}} is not sufficiently sparse to satisfy these conditions, we draw inspiration from Spielman et al. (2012) in Section 4.

8 Limitations

In line with results showing that recovering the order of batch elements is generally impossible for gradient inversion (Geiping et al., 2020; Yin et al., 2021; Geng et al., 2021; Dimitrov et al., 2022), our approach only recovers the input 𝑿𝑿{\bm{X}} up to permutation.

Further, we focus on recovering the inputs to fully connected layers such as they occur at the beginning of fully connected networks or as aggregation layers of many other architectures. Extending our approach to other layers is an interesting direction for future work. Similarly, we focus on FedSGD and believe that work on FedAvg is another interesting direction for future work.

Finally, our approach scales exponentially with batch size b𝑏b. While it is practically effective for moderate batch sizes b≲25less-than-or-similar-to𝑏25b\lesssim 25 and can be parallelized to a large degree, much larger batch sizes remain out of reach.

9 Conclusion

We propose SPEAR, the first algorithm permitting batches of b>1𝑏1b>1 elements to be recovered exactly in the honest-but-curious setting. We show theoretically and empirically that SPEAR succeeds with high probability and experimentally demonstrates that our highly parallelized GPU implementation is effective across a wide range of settings, including batches of up to 242424 elements and large networks and inputs.

We thereby demonstrate that contrary to prior belief, an exact reconstruction of batches is possible in the honest-but-curious setting, suggesting that federated learning on ReLU networks might be inherently more susceptible than previously thought. To still protect client privacy, large effective batch sizes, obtained, e.g., via secure aggregation across a large number of clients, might prove instrumental by making reconstruction computationally intractable.

10 Broader Impact

In this work, we demonstrate that contrary to prior belief, an exact reconstruction of batches is possible in the honest-but-curious setting for federated learning. As our work demonstrates the susceptibility of federated learning systems using ReLU networks, this work inevitably advances the capabilities of an adversary. Nonetheless, we believe this to be an important step in accurately assessing the risks and utilities of federated learning systems.

To still protect client privacy, large effective batch sizes, obtained, e.g., via secure aggregation across a large number of clients, might prove instrumental by making reconstruction computationally intractable. As gradient information and network states can be stored practically indefinitely, our work highlights the importance of proactively protecting client privacy in federated learning not only against current but future attacks. This underlines the importance of related work on provable privacy guarantees obtained via differential privacy.

    Uniqueness: Assume we have 𝑸1subscript𝑸1{\bm{Q}}_{1} and 𝑸2subscript𝑸2{\bm{Q}}_{2} that satisfy 𝑳​𝑸1=𝑳​𝑸2=𝑨𝑳subscript𝑸1𝑳subscript𝑸2𝑨{\bm{L}}{\bm{Q}}_{1}={\bm{L}}{\bm{Q}}_{2}={\bm{A}}. As 𝑳𝑳{\bm{L}} is of rank b𝑏b and b≤m𝑏𝑚b\leq m, there exists a left inverse 𝑳−lsuperscript𝑳𝑙{\bm{L}}^{-l} for 𝑳𝑳{\bm{L}}: 𝑳−L​𝑳=𝑰bsuperscript𝑳𝐿𝑳subscript𝑰𝑏{\bm{L}}^{-L}{\bm{L}}={\bm{I}}_{b}. Applying this left inverse to 𝑳​𝑸1=𝑳​𝑸2𝑳subscript𝑸1𝑳subscript𝑸2{\bm{L}}{\bm{Q}}_{1}={\bm{L}}{\bm{Q}}_{2}, directly yields 𝑸1=𝑸2subscript𝑸1subscript𝑸2{\bm{Q}}_{1}={\bm{Q}}_{2}, and hence we get uniqueness.

∎

Proof.

Proof.

We have the probability of one of the b𝑏b columns being all zero as b2b−1𝑏superscript2𝑏1\frac{b}{2^{b-1}} if the network has full rank, all other columns will not be all-zero.

Further, we have the probability of the submatrix 𝟙𝑨>​0subscript1subscript𝑨0\mathds{1}_{{\bm{A}}_{>}0} being full rank conditioned on column i𝑖i being all-zero as the probability of the matrix described by remaining b−1𝑏1b-1 columns being non-singular. This probability is 1−(12+ob−1​(1))b−11superscript12subscript𝑜𝑏11𝑏11-(\tfrac{1}{2}+o_{b-1}(1))^{b-1} (Tikhomirov, 2020) where limb→∞ob−1​(1)=0subscript→𝑏subscript𝑜𝑏110\lim_{b\rightarrow\infty}o_{b-1}(1)=0, which can be lower-bounded with 1−0.939b−11superscript0.939𝑏11-0.939^{b-1} (Tao & Vu, 2005). We thus obtain their joint probability as their product. ∎

Proof.

As we sample submatrices 𝑨𝑨{\bm{A}} uniformly at random with replacement, assuming them to be i.i.d. is well justified for the regime of m≫bmuch-greater-than𝑚𝑏m\gg b. The the number n𝑛n of submatrices drawn between correct direction vectors 𝒒isubscript𝒒𝑖{\bm{q}}_{i} thus follows a Geometric distribution ℙ​[n=k]=q​(1−q)k−1ℙdelimited-[]𝑛𝑘𝑞superscript1𝑞𝑘1\mathds{P}[n=k]=q(1-q)^{k-1} with success probability q𝑞q with expectation n∗=𝔼​[n]=1qsuperscript𝑛𝔼delimited-[]𝑛1𝑞n^{*}=\mathbb{E}[n]=\tfrac{1}{q}. As we draw correct direction vectors 𝒒isubscript𝒒𝑖{\bm{q}}_{i} uniformly at random from the b𝑏b columns of 𝑸¯¯𝑸\overline{{\bm{Q}}}, we have the probability of drawing a new direction vector 𝒒isubscript𝒒𝑖{\bm{q}}_{i} as b−kb𝑏𝑘𝑏\frac{b-k}{b} for k𝑘k already drawn direction vectors. Again via the expectation of the Geometric distribution we obtain the expected number c∗superscript𝑐c^{*} of correct direction vectors we have to draw until we have recovered all b𝑏b distinct ones as the solution of the Coupon Collector Problem c∗=∑k=0b−1bb−k=b​Hb≈b​log⁡(b)+γ​b+12superscript𝑐superscriptsubscript𝑘0𝑏1𝑏𝑏𝑘𝑏subscript𝐻𝑏𝑏𝑏𝛾𝑏12c^{*}=\sum_{k=0}^{b-1}\frac{b}{b-k}=bH_{b}\approx b\log(b)+\gamma b+\tfrac{1}{2}. The proof concludes with the linearity of expectation. ∎

Maximum Number of Samples Required with High Probability

We now compute the number of samples ntotalpsubscriptsuperscript𝑛𝑝totaln^{p}_{\text{total}} required to recover all b𝑏b correct directions with high probability 1−p1𝑝1-p.

Lemma A.1.

In the same setting as Lemma 5.2, we have an upper bound ntotalpsubscriptsuperscript𝑛𝑝totaln^{p}_{\text{total}} on the number of submatrices we need to sample until we have recovered all b𝑏b correct direction vectors by solving the following quadratic inequality for ntotalpsubscriptsuperscript𝑛𝑝totaln^{p}_{\text{total}}

p2≤Φ​(b​log⁡(2​b/p∗)−ntotalp​qntotalp​q​(1−q)),𝑝2Φ𝑏2𝑏superscript𝑝subscriptsuperscript𝑛𝑝total𝑞subscriptsuperscript𝑛𝑝total𝑞1𝑞\frac{p}{2}\leq\Phi\left(\frac{b\log(2b/p^{*})-n^{p}_{\text{total}}q}{\sqrt{n^{p}_{\text{total}}q(1-q)}}\right),

where ΦΦ\Phi is the cumulative distribution function of the standard normal distribution and p∗=p−1+(1−pf​r)bsuperscript𝑝𝑝1superscript1subscript𝑝𝑓𝑟𝑏p^{*}=p-1+(1-p_{fr})^{b}.

Proof.

At a high level, bound the number of valid directions cpsuperscript𝑐𝑝c^{p} we need to discover until we recover all b𝑏b distinct ones and then the number of submatrices ntotalpsubscriptsuperscript𝑛𝑝totaln^{p}_{\text{total}} we need to sample to obtain these cpsuperscript𝑐𝑝c^{p} directions, each with probability 1−p21𝑝21-\tfrac{p}{2}, before applying the union bound.

However, we first note that with probability 1−(1−pf​r)b1superscript1subscript𝑝𝑓𝑟𝑏1-(1-p_{fr})^{b} we will (repeatedly) reject a correct direction due to a lack of induced sparsity and thus fail irrespective of the number of samples we draw. We thus correct our failure probability budget from p𝑝p to p∗=p−1+(1−pf​r)bsuperscript𝑝𝑝1superscript1subscript𝑝𝑓𝑟𝑏p^{*}=p-1+(1-p_{fr})^{b}, using the union bound.

We now show how to compute the upper bound on the number of correct directions cpsuperscript𝑐𝑝c^{p} we need to find until we have found all b𝑏b distinct directions. To this end, we bound the probability of not sampling the ithsuperscript𝑖thi^{\text{th}} direction 𝒒¯isubscript¯𝒒𝑖\overline{{\bm{q}}}_{i} after finding c𝑐c candidates as p¬i=(1−1b)c≤e−cbsubscript𝑝𝑖superscript11𝑏𝑐superscript𝑒𝑐𝑏p_{\lnot i}=(1-\frac{1}{b})^{c}\leq e^{-\frac{c}{b}}. We can then bound the probability of missing any of the b𝑏b directions using the union bound as p¬all≤∑i=1bp¬i=b​e−cpbsubscript𝑝allsuperscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑏subscript𝑝𝑖𝑏superscript𝑒superscript𝑐𝑝𝑏p_{\lnot\text{all}}\leq\sum_{i=1}^{b}p_{\lnot i}=be^{-\frac{c^{p}}{b}}. We thus obtain the minimum number cpsuperscript𝑐𝑝c^{p} of correct directions to find all b𝑏b distinct ones with probability at least p∗2superscript𝑝2\tfrac{p^{*}}{2} as cp≥b​log⁡(2​b/p∗)superscript𝑐𝑝𝑏2𝑏superscript𝑝c^{p}\geq b\log(2b/p^{*}).

We can now compute the number ntotalpsubscriptsuperscript𝑛𝑝totaln^{p}_{\text{total}} of samples required to find cpsuperscript𝑐𝑝c^{p} submatrices satisfying the condition of Theorem 3.4 for some i𝑖i with probability 1−p21𝑝21-\tfrac{p}{2}. To this end, we approximate the Binomial distribution ℬ​(n,q)ℬ𝑛𝑞\mathcal{B}(n,q) with the normal distribution 𝒩​(n​q,n​q​(1−q))𝒩𝑛𝑞𝑛𝑞1𝑞\mathcal{N}(nq,nq(1-q)) (Parameswaran, 1979), which is generally precise if min⁡(n​q,n​(q−1))>9𝑛𝑞𝑛𝑞19\min(nq,n(q-1))>9 (Chen, 2011), which holds for b≥5𝑏5b\geq 5. We thus obtain the number of samples ntotalpsubscriptsuperscript𝑛𝑝totaln^{p}_{\text{total}} required to find r𝑟r valid directions with high probability 1−p∗21superscript𝑝21-\tfrac{p^{*}}{2} by solving p∗2=Φ​(cp−ntotalp​qntotalp​q​(1−q))superscript𝑝2Φsuperscript𝑐𝑝subscriptsuperscript𝑛𝑝total𝑞subscriptsuperscript𝑛𝑝total𝑞1𝑞\tfrac{p^{*}}{2}=\Phi(\frac{c^{p}-n^{p}_{\text{total}}q}{\sqrt{n^{p}_{\text{total}}q(1-q)}}) for ntotalpsubscriptsuperscript𝑛𝑝totaln^{p}_{\text{total}} which boils down to a quadratic equation.

By the union bound, we have that the total failure probability of not finding all b𝑏b correct directions is at most p𝑝p. ∎

For a batch size of b=10𝑏10b=10 and p=10−8𝑝superscript108p=10^{-8}, we, e.g., obtain n≈4×104𝑛4superscript104n\approx 4\times 10^{4}.

Proof.

We will first compute the probability of ∂ℒ∂𝒁ℒ𝒁\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial{\bm{Z}}} not containing a submatrix 𝑨𝑨{\bm{A}} satisfying the conditions of Theorem 3.4 for all i∈{1,…,b}𝑖1…𝑏i\in\{1,\dots,b\} and then the probability of us failing to discover it despite exhaustive sampling.

We observe that the number k𝑘k of rows in ∂ℒ∂𝒁ℒ𝒁\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial{\bm{Z}}} with a zero ithsuperscript𝑖thi^{\text{th}} entry is binomially distributed with success probability 1212\frac{1}{2}. For each k≥b−1𝑘𝑏1k\geq b-1, we can construct (kb−1)binomial𝑘𝑏1\binom{k}{b-1} submatrices 𝑨𝑨{\bm{A}} with an all-zero ithsuperscript𝑖thi^{\text{th}} column. The probability of any such submatrix having full rank is 1−(12−ob−1​(1))b−1>1−0.939b−11superscript12subscript𝑜𝑏11𝑏11superscript0.939𝑏11-(\frac{1}{2}-o_{b-1}(1))^{b-1}>1-0.939^{b-1} (Tikhomirov, 2020; Tao & Vu, 2005).

We thus have the probability of ∂ℒ∂𝒁ℒ𝒁\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial{\bm{Z}}} containing at least one submatrix 𝑨𝑨{\bm{A}} with full rank and an all-zero ithsuperscript𝑖thi^{\text{th}} column as ∑k=b−1m(mk)​12m​(1−0.939(b−1)​(kb−1))superscriptsubscript𝑘𝑏1𝑚binomial𝑚𝑘1superscript2𝑚1superscript0.939𝑏1binomial𝑘𝑏1\sum_{k=b-1}^{m}\binom{m}{k}\frac{1}{2^{m}}\left(1-0.939^{(b-1)\binom{k}{b-1}}\right).

Using the union bound, we thus obtain an upper bound on the probability of ∂ℒ∂𝒁ℒ𝒁\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial{\bm{Z}}} not containing any submatrix 𝑨𝑨{\bm{A}} with full rank and an all-zero ithsuperscript𝑖thi^{\text{th}} column for all i∈{1,…,b}𝑖1…𝑏i\in\{1,\dots,b\}.

To compute the probability of us failing to discover an existing submatrix despite exhaustive sampling, we first note that we have the probability pf​rsubscript𝑝𝑓𝑟p_{fr} of an arbitrary column in ∂ℒ∂𝒁ℒ𝒁\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial{\bm{Z}}} being less sparse than our threshold τ𝜏\tau. Thus, with probability 1−(1−pf​r)b1superscript1subscript𝑝𝑓𝑟𝑏1-(1-p_{fr})^{b} we will discard at least one correct direction due to it inducing an unusually dense column in ∂ℒ∂𝒁ℒ𝒁\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial{\bm{Z}}}.

We now obtain the overall failure probability via the union bound. ∎

Appendix C Dataset Licenses

In this work, we use the commonly used MNIST LeCun et al. (2010), CIFAR-10 Krizhevsky et al. (2009) and Tiny-ImageNet Le & Yang (2015) datasets. No information regarding licensing has been provided on their respective websites.

Appendix D Deferred Experiments

D.1 Experiments on Label-Heterogeneous Data

In this section, we provide additional experiments on clients with heterogeneous data. In particular, we look at the extreme case where each client has data only from a single class. As label repetition makes optimization-based attacks harder (Geiping et al., 2020; Yin et al., 2021; Geng et al., 2021), the results presented in Table 2 for the TinyImageNet dataset demonstrate another advantage of our algorithm, namely, SPEAR works regardless of the label distribution, providing even better reconstruction results compared to Table 1 for single-label batches.

D.2 Additional Experiments on Effect of Training on SPEAR

In Figure 7 in the main paper, we provided the results of evaluating SPEAR on a network in training on the same train data used for training. Here, we instead look at what happens if we evaluate the same network in training on fresh data coming from the MNIST test set. The results are presented in Figure 9. We observe similar trends, suggesting that our attack will work equally well on federated clients that already participated in the training, as on those that participate for the first time in later epochs.

D.3 Additional Experiments on Failure Probabilities

In this section, we provide more experiments validating our theoretical analysis of SPEAR’s failure rate for several additional batch sizes b𝑏b. We present our results in Figure 10, where we observe similar trends to Figure 8, reaffirming our original results.

Appendix E Visualisations of our results

Here we present a visual comparison between all batch images recovered by our method and Geiping et al. (2020) on TinyImageNet for a 6 layer fully connected network with width m=200𝑚200m=200. In Figure 11 we operate in the same setting as Section D.1, namely batches of a single class. We observe that while some images are well reconstructed by Geiping et al. (2020), most of the images are of poor visual quality, with some even being hard to recognize. In contrast, all of our recovered images are pixel perfect. This in particular also means, that SPEAR’s reconstructions improve in fine-detail recovery even upon the well recovered images of Geiping et al. (2020). This is expected as our attack is exact (up numerical errors).

Finally, we demonstrate what happens to our proposed reconstructions in the rare cases when our algorithm fails to recover a batch, i.e., it fails to find or select some of the correct directions q¯isubscript¯𝑞𝑖\overline{q}_{i}. In Figure 12, we show the one-and-only such batch for the experiment on TinyImageNet presented in Table 1. The batch had 2 wrong q¯isubscript¯𝑞𝑖\overline{q}_{i}s and still achieves an average PSNR of 91.291.291.2, which is much higher compared to prior work. Further, all but 2 images are affected by the failure.
